title: Will anyone other than Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi be proclaimed caliph before 1 October 2017?
preds:
Abu Bakr al Baghdadi Counterterrorism experts on alert after audio urges militants to fight to the death Rubinsztein-Dunlop (2017) September 29, states that: Australian counterterrorism officials fear local Islamic State supporters will be energised by a new speech believed to be by the group's reclusive leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. The audio recording was released online by the militant group overnight, fuelling US suspicions the IS leader has been in hiding on the Iraq-Syria border and not dead, casting further doubt on claims by Russia it had killed him in an air strike in May. In the rambling 46-minute recording the speaker, who sounds like Baghdadi, appears to refer to recent events, including North Korean nuclear threats to the US and Japan, as well as the "nearly year-long battle for Mosul", which fell to Iraqi forces in July. Senior Australian counterterrorism officials told the ABC they feared the speech would be a morale boost for local supporters who have been demoralised by Islamic State's retreat in Syria and Iraq (para 1-4). Rubinsztein-Dunlop, S. (2017). Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi: Counterterrorism experts on alert after audio urges militants to fight to the death. ABC. Retrieved from
http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-29/counter-terrorism-experts-on-alert-after-audio-of-baghdadi/8999914

Given the latest announcement and the date, it is highly unlikely any change will occur by Oct 1.
I think values less than 1% should be allowed when there are multiple options

Maintaining forecast given time frame remaining: A recent CNN article states the reasons for the uncertainty of Baghdadi’s death:
“Over the summer, the U.S. believed they had their best shot at killing terrorist leader, Baghdadi, in an airstrike, according to several U.S. officials.”
“The strike, which has never been publicly disclosed was based on intelligence that indicated a senior ISIS leader, quite possibly Baghdadi, was at the particular location.” 
“The officials familiar with the strike tell CNN it has never been definitively determined if Baghdadi was actually killed.” 
“One of the reasons the U.S. remains uncertain if it killed Baghdadi is that in the days and weeks that followed the strike, U.S. intelligence did not intercept any ISIS communications confirming his death…” 
(http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/14/politics/us-isis-baghdadi/index.html)  Additional reading: IS losing ground in Raqqa (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-41332750), and a new assault in Anbar province (https://www.stripes.com/news/middle-east/iraqi-forces-launch-battle-against-isis-footholds-in-vast-anbar-province-1.488447#.WcqstjMfnq0)

he is leadding isis for that long, that their is noway that he will be replaced while alive. if he is is dead they would need a "strong" successor (due to them loosing ground). keeping him "alive" seems more like it
Based on numerous reports of his death and yet no confirmation post Mosul or Tal Afar - unlikely.  Leaders are in hiding and the network is destabilized.
No time left and information flow is slow and currently he is still alive. Even if dead by this second there would not be a definite answer who will follow him
Because IS would not admit to his death even if it occurs.
Because he wouldn't give up power, but could be killed by a coalition or Russian airstrike upon discovery, however its a short time period

The month September is almost over and we are nearing the first of October. 
Baghdadi has neither been killed nor is there any sign of him wanting to give up his post as Caliph.

Don't really have a process on this one, I'm just putting the odds on him being killed AND a new Caliph being announced in the next two weeks as extremely low probability. I don't see any reason why he would step down in this timeframe as well.
Updating to reflect upcoming close date (Oct. 1).  "No" is now more likely.
Even if he is dead, IS will have no incentive to declare him dead.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Isis is wounded and on the hop so unlikely to be proclaiming anything! Latest reports say Baghdadi is still alive, so he would remain caliph.
As nice as it would be, I don't think this is happening in the next two weeks.

“A U.S. special operations task force tracked and killed three leaders, who allegedly oversaw weapons research and drone operations, in the valley this week, officials said.” (http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-isis-intel-20170908-story.html) 
This is the area that Baghdadi is presumed to be located - even if he’s a target within the next two weeks, the group may not be sufficiently organised as to elect a new caliph in the remaining time frame.

Baghdadi is more than just a spiritual leader for ISIS. He is the Caliph, the "rightful heir" to a line of Caliphs decended from the hand picked successors to Muhammed himself. His death will be disputed for years just as Bin Laden's was, and it is likely that thousands of hours of pre recorded sermons and speeches of his remain somewhere encrypted, hiding on the web.

The jihadist group, which has used prophecies of an imminent apocalypse to marshal militants from around the world, is about to face its own End of Days on the battlefields of Syria and Iraq. Syrian government forces, backed by Iranian militias and spurred on by Russian air strikes, broke through IS’s defences around the eastern city of Deir ez-Zor on September 5th. Bashar al-Assad’s regime is preparing an assault to retake the entire city, ending the jihadists’ control over their last urban stronghold. Territorially, the militants are on the verge of defeat. They have lost about 90% of their “caliphate” in Iraq and 85% of their territory in Syria. American and Russian air strikes are picking off the group’s leaders as they hide in towns and villages south of Deir ez-Zor. The prophesied destruction of the crusader armies will have to wait

"Daesh leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is dead, Syrian war monitor says"
"Baghdadi’s apparent death or capture has been asserted several times over the past decade as his breakaway Al Qaeda faction gradually formed into Daesh. But the various reports later proved false or could not be substantiated."
https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2017/07/11/daesh-leader-abu-bakr-al-baghdadi-is-dead-syrian-war-monitor-says.html Aug 31st: "The U.S. commander of forces fighting the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria believes the militants’ top leader is still alive. " (http://globalnews.ca/news/3710716/islamic-state-leader-abu-bakr-al-baghdadi-likely-alive/)

Based on consensus. Even if his death is confirmed in the next few weeks, chances of an official proclamation of a new leader seems highly unlikely. With their PR taking a hit with dwindling strongholds, they probably won't want to look even more disorganized.
(This forecast is the product of perverse incentives.)
Because I think he is still alive . Or, if he isn't, admitting his death would make ISIS  look weak, which would be detrimental to their collective ego, especially at their current 'low point'.

Even he's dead, we assume he's alive until proven. Who can contest Baghdadi when he's alive? The biggest competitor is AQ, but Zawahiri already denounced him and the org is unlikely to contest sth they don't recognize. The claim can still come from a smaller group to benefit from the uncertainty around whether Baghdadi is dead or alive. Who can be the successor if he's dead? ISIS will need a leader and a new caliph would likely follow, but not sure who he will that be. We cannot rule out yet that he's not going to be declared dead before 1 October and a new caliphate will not be announced.

I have no idea if this man is dead or alive, but time is running out. If he's dead, and there has been no declaration of a new caliph by now, there is not likely to be in the next 3 weeks. If he's alive, he would have to be killed and replaced officially in three weeks. Unlikely.

1) US general thinks Baghdadi is probably still alive
2) just over three weeks left

Looks like Russian claim is going unconfirmed.
Dropping back to to 1% because there is not much time left.
Even if he dies, they won't want us to know
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Baghdadi's already dead, isn't he? Didn't the Russians say so? Anyway, the politics of the various factions in the insurgent groups are unclear, and the basis for establishing a caliphate is contested. It doesn't seem that a consensus will be arrived at easily.

Long (very long!) and detailed article about 'The Workshop' of IS: http://spioenkop.blogspot.nl/2017/08/armour-in-islamic-state-story-of.html?m=1 "Despite the fact that the Coalition struck 'The Workshop' on the 30th of August 2016, it remains unknown if they were ever fully aware of the exact nature of the facility, possibly only striking the BMP because it was discovered by accident. While one could argue that Coalition intelligence should have been able to identify this facility early on with the amount of resources it possesses, the fact that more than 150 armoured fighting vehicles could be overhauled and upgraded here seems to directly contradict this possibility. While regime forces not only captured the facility, but would also be presented with large numbers of photographs taken inside 'The Workshop', it is likely that the sheer inefficiency of the Syrian military apparatus prevented any action to be taken against it. (...) several other members of the 'Tank Battalion' and technicians of 'The Workshop' could also be identified thanks to their presence on social media. While Twitter had already declared war on designated terrorist groups in 2014, banning the accounts of Islamic State fighters and its supporters, large numbers of Islamic State fighters continue to maintain accounts on various other social media platforms, most notably Facebook. The author made several attempts to get in contact with several of these individuals by posing as a member of a different unit from the 'Tank Battalion' for the gathering of information and photographs of their operations and daily life in Syria, leading to the removal of the account by Facebook on several occasions. Ironically, many of the accounts of the Islamic State fighters in question remain present on Facebook to this day. Although it is extremely likely that foreign fighters played a vital role in running 'The Workshop', their presence here could not be verified. Many of the Islamic State tankers active on Facebook are not only friends with each other, but also with fighters of various other factions fighting for control over Syria. Indeed, most appear to have bonded by their shared passion for armoured fighting vehicles, choosing to ignore whatever religious beliefs and other differences may divide them. Posing with their tanks, photographing them from different angles and even becoming members of tank enthusiast groups on Facebook, their presence on social media certainly provides for an interesting insight into the life of Islamic State fighters one doesn't get to see often. "

Top commander says ISIS leader most likely still alive
http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/31/abu-bakr-al-baghdadi-likely-alive-242210

Lowering forecast:  Considering it increasingly unlikely that IS will be able to elect a new Caliph with nearly 1 month to go.
The group appears to still have the ability, albeit slightly, to coordinate; the recent cease-fire between Hezbollah, the Syrian Regime and Islamic State, made way for IS to transport about 670 IS terrorists and their families heading for Deir al-Zour. Though the US-coalition said they’ve stopped the convoy reaching their destination. 
https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1294971/coalition-strikes-block-highway-used-by-fleeing-terrorists/
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/30/world/middleeast/isis-syria-lebanon-us-military.html?_r=0 Whether Baghdadi is the target of a potential airstrike or raid is important as previous terrorist organisations, such as the Taliban, have denied the death of their leaders by airstrike. Where as, in the case of Al-Qaeda, Bin-Laden being the target of a raid was irrefutable. That being said, there was approximately 46 days between Al-Qaeda confirming Bin-Laden’s death and announcing Ayman al-Zawahiri as the next commander. 
Russia claims Baghdadi was killed in an airstrike, where as the U.S. believe Baghdadi is still alive, hence I’ve given a 7% probability of another Caliph after Baghdadi’s death.

Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was announced to be death by russian army. Confirmed by Syrian Human Rights Watch NGO.
This death is not 100% sure and a new calife should be named shortly after official confirmation by Daesh.

Lowering forecast: U.S. Brigadier General Andrew Croft said that over the past two or three months, he had seen a fracturing in the Islamic State leadership. “It just seems less coordinated. It appears more fractured, less robust, and sort of flimsy, is the word I would use…it is sporadic.” (http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-mideast-crisis-usa-iraq-idUKKCN1B20F8?il=0). A fractured leadership would certainly make it harder for the relevant figures to come together and elect a new caliph.  The Secretary of Defense, James Mattis said: “You see, ISIS is now caught in-between converging forces. So ISIS’s days are certainly numbered, but it’s not over yet and its not going to be over anytime soon” (http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/08/22/mattis-isis-militants-caught-iraq-syria-military-vise.html) 
Baghdadi’s life, if not already ended, is constantly at risk (hence, 9%) - on the other hand he could make it past October 1.

Time is running out, but I think that the possibility that there will be some kind of major shake up in ISIL is underestimated. As to his death, others have mentioned that ISIL is reticent to announce deaths or other internal issues that would signify instability. That leaves the possibility that he may already be dead. EID is Spetmeber 1 so this would provide good timing for a major announcement.
Final 20% to no since I've been yes for so long.

Lowering the second category slightly as time is ticking away.  In the book ‘The Early Islamic Conquests’, Fred Donner argues “that standard Arabian practice during the early caliphates was for the prominent men of a kinship group, or tribe, to gather after a leaders death and elect a leader amongst themselves.” (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caliphate#Electing_or_appointing_a_Caliph). Given that ISIS aims to follow the early days of Islam, the only legitimate Caliph would be one who is elected.
For the question to resolve ‘yes, after Baghdadi’s death’; within 6 weeks, Baghdadi must be proven dead and the mijals must elect a new Caliph. I don’t know how quickly these things move but given that the deputies are targets of the global coalition, the shura council members meeting in one location would mean a big target hanging over their heads, so they may decide to communicate in alternative ways. 
An article published on the Independent a couple years ago states: “a Caliphate in the history of Islam does not have a successor. The same was for the Prophet Mohammad. If Baghdadi is establishing the old Caliphate and ruling 'by the book', he wouldn't appoint a ‘second-in-command’.” (http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/is-isis-replacing-its-injured-leader-abu-bakr-al-baghdadi-with-a-former-physics-teacher-10199521.html) 
Considering that there may not be a successor, a Caliph declared in this time frame is looking unlikely.

So-called ISIS (and other terrorist groups) have a track record of obfuscating details of the deaths of their leaders to ensure that their organizations appear unaffected by actions against them. Local sources in Syria, indicate he was killed by Russian action in early July, so it appears likely they will be able to keep the truth hidden until Oct 1.
Middle bucket down 10% for passage of time. Perhaps I was wrong and he is more useful alive rather than dead.

Recent events in Mosul and Raqqa suggest that ISIS's current pillar of power is collapsing.  Reports of Baghdadi's death have already surfaced and ISIS's influence continues to recede.  Most ISIS related attacks are lone wolfs whose main motivation is the propaganda released by ISIS.  If Baghdadi is really dead, an internal power struggle will most likely occur which could split the faction producing an entirely new organization altogether.

Maintaining forecast: The Iraqi forces are preparing to invade Tal Afar: “The coalition continues to support the Iraqis as they reset and prepare for follow-on operations in Tal Afar, which Navy Capt. Jeff Davis said “is effectively surrounded at this point and we’ll continue to see that tighten as time goes on” (https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1270692/on-third-anniversary-of-isis-fight-5-million-are-free-from-terrorist-army/)  The report also stated more air strikes took place in Huwayjah, Kisik, Rajah and Tal Afar. I still think its possible that Baghdadi (if he’s not dead) is located and targeted, and given that we have under 2 months left on this timeline, this could be sufficient time for ISIS to declare Baghdadi’s successor. That being said, the coalition’s strategy seems to be ‘take out senior leaders and deputies’ to disrupt the leadership structure - so the militants poised to succeed Baghdadi, as elected by the Shura council, may be killed in this time, in which case it could take longer to have a legitimate Caliph declared.

This question is somewhat undefined.  I am interpreting this to be proclaimed by ISIS as a group.  In order for that to occur, ISIS would have to have consensus on who the caliph is. More importantly however, the Caliphate only makes sense with a state to attach it to and it seems unlikely another one would be proclaimed as ISIS is losing control of territory and on the verge of ceasing to be a state.

Anyone think these two articles are reputable enough to consider this complete?
1) Baghdadi is dead:
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4685292/ISIS-admits-leader-Abu-Bakr-al-Baghdadi-dead.html 2) Another ISIS member Abu Haitham al-Obaidi proclaimed himself caliph:
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4688302/Senior-ISIS-member-declares-new-caliph-Iraq.html Or do we wait for the Spicer of the ISIS community to issue a presser?
Shifting 10% to no for passage of time.
There is no reason to claim caliph leadership for another radical-islamic leader. It has not proven to be a very successful strategy.

ISIS is continuing to lose territory necessary for their caliphate:  The Syrian Democratic Forces have been making progress in Raqqa: “SDF are on the verge of seizing full control of the southern neighbourhoods, a kurdish official said” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-raqqa-idUSKBN1AH3RF). It seems the current strategy coalition forces are using is effective in making ISIS disorientated. Col. Ryan Dillon said “We’ve seen less coherent ISIS defence in Raqqa compared to Mosul. ISIS is still using car bombs, booby traps and civilians to hide behind, but their inability to address the multiple advances is apparent” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-raqqa-idUSKBN1AH3RF) 
The Iraqi government is also preparing to retake Tal Afar in Iraq. (https://www.stripes.com/news/us-troops-aiding-iraqis-before-looming-isis-battle-in-tal-afar-1.480859#.WYBerTMfn-Y)  Fighting is still underway in Marawi, Philippines. According to Lt. Col. Jo-Ar Herrera, fighting in Marawi has “been contained to a small area of the city, with 60 to 70 militants holding about 100 hostages” (https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/07/26/isis-philippines-marawi-fighting/502025001/).
 “U.S. Special Operations Forces have been assisting the AFP with ongoing operations in Marawi mainly by providing information and intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance assistance to AFP commanders in their fight against Maute and Abu Sayyaf Group militants”. (https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1261831/us-delivers-two-c-208b-aircraft-to-philippine-air-force/) 
From reading several reports, the city is expected to be liberated in a couple months (at most) - though President Duterte has extended martial law until the end of the year. Because of this response, the probability of ISIS capturing enough land to declare a Caliphate in Southeast Asia is low. 
In Libya: according to a report; “militias fighting on behalf of Libya’s UN backed government have warned that ISIS militants are regrouping in order to launch a new attack on the city of Misrata” (http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-regrouping-libya-forces-mosul-raqqa-islamic-state-syria-iraq-islamic-state-a7862606.html).  An article on iraqinews.com stated: “Several Islamic State members were killed and wounded after internal splits ignited infighting among the militants in Kirkuk”. According to a source “Clashes took place over disagreements regarding the distribution of ranks and allegiance to Baghdadi” (http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/islamic-state-infighting-leaves-many-members-dead-kirkuk/) 
From the report on infighting, its possible that after Baghdadi’s death a number of militants will come forward claiming to be Caliph (as has been previously discussed). Therefore, lowering for yes given that we only have two months left on this timeline; so if Baghdadi is killed soon, what are the chances of it being announced in this time? And could the question be resolved if a number of fighters come forward claiming to be Caliph?
I think that this war will be done
Shifting 20% to no for passage of time.

Looked through the comments below and read through the articles a few people posted. It seems as if he is not actually dead ( as a new Caliph would have already been decided), and that IS is only saying he is to protect and hide him more effectively. If/when Baghdadi's dies, a new Caliph will be proclaimed almost instantly, which could be within the next few months, yet unlikely.

Adjusting forecast:  I have only just learned that the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights obtained confirmation on Baghdadi’s death from senior I.S. commanders. (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/21/us/politics/mattis-islamic-state-leader-alive.html?_r=0). With Defense Secretary Jim Mattis saying he believes “the leader of IS is still alive and that the American-led coalition in Iraq and Syria was still trying to find and target him”, and a top Kurdish counter-terrorism official saying he was “99% sure Baghdadi is alive and located south of the Syrian City of Raqqa” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-baghdadi-idUSKBN1A20JD); I’m starting to think senior Islamic State fighters want the world to believe Baghdadi is dead to protect him?  There is still just over 2 months left for Baghdadi’s location to be identified and become the target of a strike or raid. Army Gen. Raymond A. Thomas III (Commander of U.S. Special Operations Command) said, at the Aspen Security Forum, he does not know whether Baghdadi is alive, but if he’s not dead “there is not a safe place for him on this Earth. We absolutely dismantled his network; everyone who worked for him initially is dead or gone. Everyone who stepped to the late following - - dead or gone. Down through a network where we have killed, at a conservative estimate 60,000 of his followers - - his army.” (https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1255158/special-ops-capabilities-relevant-around-the-world-commander-says/)  On the topic of Raqqa: “Advances against the Islamic State group in Raqqa have slowed down amid stiff resistance from the militants. U.S. Army Col. Ryan Dillon estimates there are around 2000 fighters in the northern city, saying they are using civilians and children as human shields.” (http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/07/21/us-official-isis-putting-stiff-resistance-syria-raqqa.html).
Learning from the fight in Mosul, IS know how to slow the security forces down and draw out the fight. Therefore, it’s likely the Caliphate will still exist by October 1st.

at 6:45 a.m.: “The Failing New York Times foiled U.S. attempt to kill the single most wanted terrorist,Al-Baghdadi.Their sick agenda over National Security”  After reading that tweet from Trump it occurred to me that If al-Baghdadi was dead, he'd know, be bragging about it, and not making tweets like this.
No power vacuum to fill until position of geographical strength can be achieved
Shifting another 20% to no on no death confirmation and passage of time.

http://www.independent.ie/world-news/spotlight/the-massacre-of-mosul-40000-civilians-feared-dead-in-battle-to-liberate-city-from-isis-35949240.html Asked if the self-declared caliph Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is alive or dead, Mr Zebari said he did not know. But he added that, if Baghdadi was dead, it was strange that no new caliph or Isis leader had been declared since part of the ideology of such movements is that they do not rely on a single human being. Successors had been quickly announced when Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq, was killed in a US air strike in 2006 and Osama bin Laden was shot dead by US special forces in Pakistan in 2011. Moreover, he says that there “has been no sign of a change in the Isis command and control structure”.
After his death yes but that is not likely by October 1, 2017.
Attack on Raqqa is going faster than I expected, so I assign the Yes-options slightly higher weight.
Trying to be too clever, chasing points!! No comments etc etc broke all my rules!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-baghdadi-idUSKBN1A20JD
The Kurds--who are at the moment the most nearly reliable source in that part of the world-- say he's okay, or at least not dead.   Schrodinger's caliph?
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Three questions:  is Baghdadi dead?  Will they name a new caliph (one person) to replace him?  Will they do so by 1 October?    50 percent chance he is dead. If he is dead, 90 percent chance they decide on one person to replace him (rather than rule by committee), 70 percent chance they decide on his replacement by 1 October

Adjusting forecast, thanks for the comments @Rene and @Khalid. 
Might be jumping too quickly on this, but we've still got 3 months to figure out if there is a true Caliph.

@Rene and reports that someone called Abu Haitham al Obeidi has claimed to be his successor.  Depending on how cohesive the organization is, there could be a number of claimants, and then we'll have the problem of deciding which if any has been "proclaimed" rightfully.

"After reporter Chad Garland inquired with CENTCOM’s press office about the rumor about Baghdadi’s death, CENTCOM responded, “We strongly advise ISIS to implement a long line of succession.”" https://heavy.com/news/2017/07/abu-haitham-al-obeidi-new-isis-islamic-state-leader-caliph-pictures-photos/ PS I'm not sure if ISIS will play by the normal rules of succession (having territory as a necessary condition)
I expect him to live a couple more months and don't expect him to cede power to someone else.

Syrian Observatory says it has 'confirmed information' that Islamic State chief is dead Barrington and Francis (2017) Tue Jul 11, states that: The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights told Reuters on Tuesday that it had "confirmed information" that Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has been killed. The report came just days after the Iraqi army recaptured the last sectors of the northern Iraqi city of Mosul, which Baghdadi's forces overran almost exactly three years ago. Russia's Defence Ministry said in June that it might have killed Baghdadi when one of its air strikes hit a gathering of Islamic State commanders on the outskirts of the Syrian city of Raqqa. But Washington said it could not corroborate the death and Western and Iraqi officials have been skeptical. Reuters could not independently verify Baghdadi's death (para. 1-4). Barrington, L. & Francis, E. (2017). Syrian Observatory says it has 'confirmed information' that Islamic State chief is dead. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-baghdadi-idUSKBN19W1AW

According to this source a new caliph has already been named: 
https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/isil-members-claim-baghdadi-killed-al-sumaria-tv/
http://ifpnews.com/exclusive/isis-confirm-leaders-death/ Leaving 2% chance that the anonymous IS source is incorrect in naming a source and it still need to be discussed.  I could not find the new name.
No one else will be Caliph.
Shifting toward no because even if Baghdadi is dead I don't think it'll be announced.

Still no confirmation on whether Baghdadi has been killed: With Mosul “liberated” and the fight for Raqqa underway, ISIS is losing ground. However, according to a BBC article, one of the areas along the Iraq/Syria border the militants still control, Wilayat al-Furat, is the only remaining region where IS can claim ‘ardh tamkeen’. (See @Wildwood2000’s comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/525026)
“No campaign has been launched yet to liberate the remote towns. Discussion as to whether the US or Syrian Government and its allies should lead the offensive on the Syrian side of the border are still being held in Washington”. 
In which case, ISIS has the land, thus it’s still possible that another Caliph could be declared before 1 October 2017 - if Baghdadi is dead.
If Baghdadi is not dead he is believed to be in this area, according to Hisham al-Hashimi, an adviser to the Iraqi government and an expert on Iraqi jihadist groups. (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-40479361) - the article does cite a recent video released from Raqqa after the Russians claimed they had killed Baghdadi, of IS members referring to “our Sheik” without mentioning Baghdadi. 
High-value targets tend to be located in remote areas, this includes Wilayat al-Furat, which would make it a target for drone strikes. Coming back to @Wildwood2000’s comment from a couple of weeks ago, the members of the Shoura council “would be unlikely to meet for security reasons” (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/525026). Any indication of high-ranking IS members meeting at a single location would definitely draw the attention of a strike, leading to the loss of more IS leadership - unless for strategic reasons, i.e. intelligence gathering.  It’s possible, as has been previously mentioned, that ISIS will not admit Baghdadi is dead for some time.
The Afghan Taliban “covered up the death of leader Mullah Omar for more than two years. It was kept secret on tactical grounds” 
“Mullah Mansour, Omars deputy was appointed leader the day after his death was announced.”
(http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34105565)
Osama Bin Laden was killed May 2nd, 2011; Al-Qaeda confirmed his death on May 6th, 2011 and Ayman al-Zawahiri assumed the role of commander June 16th, 2011. 
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda#Osama_bi_Laden_.281987_-_May_2011.29 - not the most reliable source however) 
Neither of the aforementioned terrorist organisations follow the appointment of Caliph however, therefore they do not follow the process of an elective council in the same way a caliphate would.  I still think its more likely another Caliph will not be appointed before 1 October, when taking into account the time it took the Taliban and Al-Qaeda to fill the position; and the ongoing fight in Raqqa/ending fight in Mosul takes precedence and could lead to disagreements amongst ISIS leadership.

As long as they control a village or maybe even a building, there is land for someone to be caliph about, which can be stretched to meet at least one of the criteria  There are other technical requirements, easily fudged in an emergency--and ISIL hasn't been all that punctilious about obeying the rules of Islam in other matters anyway.   So if he's dead, somebody may decide to take it upon himself, in all humility of course--the passive voice of the question allows that to count as a Yes, with or without formal endorsement of the claim by anybody else--or the surviving leadership may think they need a figurehead.  On the other hand, the surviving leadership have enough on their plate without opening up the possibility of dueling caliphs, if he's dead.  Even if he's not dead, there is a small probability of whatever you call a palace revolt when there isn't any palace, prompted by his obvious inability to keep it together for the team.

Islamic State nears its end The Economist (2017) July 5th, states that: THE fireworks have been ordered. Street parties are planned. The Iraqi government has prepared a week of festivities to mark the fall of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi’s self-proclaimed caliphate. Three years after seizing control of the great alluvial plains of the Tigris and Euphrates, Islamic State (IS), which has claimed so many victims in north-western Iraq, Syria and beyond, is finally dying. American-led forces in Syria breached the old city walls of IS’s capital, Raqqa, on July 4th. In Mosul, in Iraq, all but the last alleyways of the Old City were back in government hands as The Economist went to press. Finding a backdrop from which to celebrate the liberation of Mosul will be difficult, though. Between them, IS and the coalition have destroyed too many shrines and mosques to leave much of historic value, including the al-Nuri mosque dating back to Crusader times from where Mr Baghdadi proclaimed himself caliph. Gone is the Jewish quarter, the markets with their monasteries, and the lattice balconies and sculptured masonry of another Sunni silk road city. “Overlooking the Tigris, there could be no nobler or more beautiful place to sit in,” waxed Ibn Jubayr, a Spanish travel writer who visited in the 12th century. What one side booby-trapped, the other side shelled. Almost half the neighbourhoods of west Mosul have been destroyed, including much of the Old City, estimates a foreign observer, perhaps some 20,000 houses in all. “Like Dresden,” an American general was heard muttering, touring the ruins (para. 1-2). The Economist Website. (2017). Islamic State nears its end. The Economist. Middle East and Africa. Retrieved from

In fierce fighting, Iraqi army units forced the insurgents back into a shrinking rectangle no more than 300 by 500 meters beside the Tigris river, according to a map published by the military media office. Smoke covered parts of the Old City, which were rocked by air strikes and artillery salvos through the morning. The number of Islamic State (IS) militants fighting in Mosul has dwindled from thousands at the start of the government offensive more than eight months ago to a mere couple of hundred now, according to the Iraqi military. Iraqi forces say they expect to reach the Tigris and regain full control over the city by the end of this week. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi is expected to visit Mosul to formally declare victory, and a week of nationwide celebrations is planned. Mosul is by far the largest city captured by Islamic State. It was here, nearly three years ago to the day, that it declared the founding of its "caliphate" over parts of Iraq and Syria. With Mosul gone, its territory in Iraq will be limited to areas west and south of the city where some tens of thousands of civilians live. "Victory is very near, only 300 meters separate the security forces from the Tigris," military spokesman Brigadier General Yahya Rasool told state TV (para. 1-7). Baghdadi has left the fighting in Mosul to local commanders and is believed to be hiding near the Iraq-Syrian border, according to U.S. and Iraqi military sources (para. 17). The group has moved its remaining command and control structures to Mayadin, in eastern Syria, U.S. intelligence sources have said (para. 17-18). Kalin, S. & Chmaytelli, M. (2017). 2-part post.
Part 1.
I read multiple questions and assumptions between the proposed question+ the more info section + answer options; so stripping them apart is my part 1. I’m all for collaborators to add to this list. Part II. will be the probabilities after I’ve had some time to research each factor laid-out here. In the question itself is really two distinct considerations: 
1- Will he be the caliph of IS on 1 October? 
•	this would’ve been a garden variety GJ question, that would probably entail most of the analysis we’re going to have to do anyways. So, I assume they didn’t ask it for a reason, though its irrelevant to figuring this out.
2- Will someone else be the caliph of IS on 1 October? 
•	Who? How? When? Where? Why? There’s a lot more to this part of the question than the first because it assumes the perpetuity of IS in the sense that if its leader is not going to be al-Baghdadi, then it has to be someone else, because IS isn’t going away; it also assumes they have to have a caliph at all. Which means the questions -who/what/when/where/why- are more about the technical workings and stability of the Islamic State, rather than the individual “someone else” in question.  In the ‘more info’ section:
Others have pointed out the uncertainty around who/what mechanism would actually do the “be proclaimed” bit. I think the more info section scopes the conversation to the current Islamic State which al-Baghdadi leads. Thus, if there is a reasonable likelihood that a street vendor in Morocco or a devout follower in Nebraska could proclaim himself to be caliph AND the IS acknowledge that by some process/event/media, then that should be factored into the probability; I’m just not familiar with whether there is a ‘process’ here to be researched. Imo, the reality is, its very unlikely both things would happen (a loner claiming to be caliph AND the IS proclaiming him as such). So, whether it would count or not, I don’t think it has much effect on where we’ll end up overall because its already such a low likelihood) Also in the more information: “continues to hammer at the IS”; this statement combined with the articles provided shine a light on needing to factor in the dissolution of Islamic State from defeat, its potential fracturing from internal turmoil/betrayal, or maybe one of the Islamaic State arms outside of Iraq and Syria causing an IS split… Can there be two caliphs? What would that look like? Who would challenge al-Baghdadi? In the answer options:
first option: a few scenarios could unfold that resolve here
- he leaves voluntarily and IS proclaims a replacement
- he leaves involuntarily and IS proclaims a replacement
- an Islamic State province directly challenges his position, with another/new leader proclaimed by the members of that province to be Caliph
- IS declares it has two caliphs, and just names another one second option – he dies, and he’s replaced
- natural causes
- natural disaster
- bullet between the eyes third option – this is status quo and at the outset, is my highest probability. Purposeful and planned change takes a long time…and the more pieces involved, the longer it takes-- 228 days is not long. And I'm not sure if research will support that there is a move underway for IS leadership change. So to come down on ‘No”, and increase the others,  l’m mostly looking for black swan stuff, and/or tremendous change to IS…
